reasoning:
The critique targets the choice to define “best feasible future” as the 99.99th percentile. That benchmark is part of the paper’s formalism, but it is largely a stipulation/normalization device rather than a substantive premise; the core “no easy eutopia” case rests on claims about moral fragility, fat-tailed value-efficiency, and structural properties of value functions, which would mostly survive changing this percentile. So centrality is limited.

Strength is low because varying the percentile mostly changes labels/thresholds (“best feasible”, “mostly-great”) rather than showing that, relative to a fixed notion of near-optimality, near-best futures are actually common. In particular, saying “if you redefine best feasible to be less extreme, more futures count as mostly-great” is close to a definitional point, not a refutation. The critique also overstates dependence: the paper explicitly notes there’s nothing magical about the thresholds and uses them for convenience.

Correctness is moderate: it is true the paper offers limited principled justification for 99.99 specifically, and some numeric illustrations would shift under other cutoffs. But the critique’s claim that the paper’s main conclusion could “reverse” with modest changes is not well-supported and likely false given the argument’s qualitative backbone.

Clarity is high, dead weight is minimal, and it focuses on a single issue.
title: The 99.99th percentile benchmark is arbitrary and conclusion-determining
